Although the two terms are sometimes used interchangeably in the literature, they can be distinguished by exposure paradigms. Adaptation is evidenced by differences in responses to a single vs. repeated exposures at a single concentration. In contrast, tolerance to O 3 Fig. S1 Mechanisms underlying tolerance to O 3 3 Nambu and Yokoyama 1982 Evans et al. 1985 Evans et al. 1985 3 Nambu and Yokoyama 1983 Wiester et al. 2000 Nambu and Yokoyama (1983) Evans et al. (1985) 3 Although previous studies have focused on the role of epithelial cells, we sought to evaluate the role of alveolar macrophages (AMs) in tolerance to O 3 3 Pendino et al. 1995 Dahl et al. 2007 Tighe et al. 2011 Sunil et al. 2012 Hussain et al. 2020 Guttenberg et al. 2024 3 Tovar et al. 2020 Choudhary et al. 2021 Tovar et al. 2022 Previous studies have shown that macrophages play key roles in adaptation to other stimuli, e.g. endotoxin and chlorine gas ( Foster et al., 2007 Allard et al., 2019 3 3 Nambu and Yokoyama 1982 Nambu and Yokoyama 1983 Evans et al. 1985 van der Wal et al. 1994 Materials and methods Mice Multiple studies have reported differences in O 3 Cabello et al. 2015 Mishra et al. 2016 Cho et al. 2019 Birukova et al. 2019 Yaeger et al. 2021 3 Cabello et al. 2015 Mishra et al. 2016 Birukova et al. 2019 O 3 Mice were exposed to filtered air (FA) or 0.8 ppm O 3 3 Fig. 1A Evans et al. 1985 van Bree et al. 2002 3 3 Smith et al. 2019 Lung phenotyping At designated time points, mice were anesthetized (2 g/kg urethane) and sacrificed by inferior vena cava/abdominal aorta exsanguination. Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) was performed by instilling the lungs with phosphate buffered saline (PBS) containing a protease inhibitor cocktail (Roche Cat. No. 11836170001) two times, first with 0.5 ml and then with 1.0 ml. The BAL fluid was centrifuged for 10 min at 400 × g ○ g For lung histopathology, the left lobe was immersion fixed in 10% neutral buffered formalin for 24 h. After formalin fixation, lung lobes were stored in 70% ethanol until further tissue processing for light microscopic examination. Five-micron-thick, formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded tissue sections were prepared on positively charged slides and stained with hematoxylin and eosin or processed for immunohistochemistry using the following antibodies and conditions. Non-specific proteins were blocked with Rodent Block M (catalog #: RBM961, Biocare). Primary antibody for FOXJ1 (monoclonal rat anti-mouse HFH4, clone EPR21874 Total BAL protein was quantified with the Qubit Total Protein Quantification kit and the Qubit 2.0 fluorometer (Thermo Scientific). BAL albumin was quantified with a mouse albumin ELISA kit (E-90AL, Immunology Consultants Laboratory). BAL cytokines were measured using a MILLIPLEX protein immunoassay (Millipore) that was read on a Bio-Plex 200 multiplex suspension array system (Bio-Rad). Clodronate treatment PBS or clodronate (5 mg/ml) containing liposomes (Liposoma, Amsterdam, The Netherlands) were administered to mice by oropharyngeal aspiration on day 5 of the O 3 Adoptive transfer of AMs Mice were exposed to FA or 0.8 ppm O 3 n 3 Preparation and analysis of epithelial populations by multi-color flow cytometry Lungs were digested by intratracheal instillation via a 20-gauge catheter of 1 ml of 5 mg/ml collagenase I (Worthington Biochemical Corp, Lakewood, NJ) and 0.25 mg/ml DNase I (Sigma) prepared in RPMI media (Life Technologies, Carlsbad, CA) prior to instilling 0.5 ml of 1% (wt/vol) low melting agarose (Amresco, Solon, OH), similar to previous protocols ( Dial et al. 2017 Mock et al. 2019 2020a Mock et al. 2020a 6 Table S1 Table S1 Flow cytometry of epithelial populations was performed using a Cytoflex flow cytometer (Beckman Coulter, Brea, CA) and analyzed using CytExpert (Beckman Coulter) software, version 2.4, and the gating strategy is shown in Fig. S2 Dial et al. 2017 Mock et al. 2019 Mock et al. 2020b Preparation and analysis of leukocyte populations by multi-color flow cytometry Murine lung leukocytes were isolated and analyzed by flow cytometry as previously described ( Immormino et al. 2018 Table S1 Flow cytometry on leukocyte populations was performed using a four-laser LSRII (BD Biosciences) or a five-laser Fortessa (BD Biosciences) cytometer and analyzed using FlowJo (Treestar, Ashland, OR) software. Only single cells were analyzed, and leukocyte populations were identified using a manual gating strategy depicted in Fig. S3 Statistical analyses For the analyses of phenotypes in the model of tolerance ( Fig. 1 3 3 t 3 3 3 Fig. 1A 3 3 Fig. 1A Fig. 5 t 3 3 3 3 t AM gene expression analysis by RNA sequencing RNA-sequencing analysis was conducted on AMs isolated from mice on day 7 of the tolerance model. Total RNA was extracted from two batches of flow-sorted AMs using QIAGEN RNeasy kits per the manufacturer’s instructions. RNA integrity was analyzed using an Agilent Bioanalyzer. RIN values ranged from 8.9 to 9.7, indicating intact RNA. PolyA + RNA libraries were prepared with the Roche Kapa mRNA stranded library preparation kit as per the manufacturer's instructions. Paired-end sequencing (50 cycles) was performed on an Illumina NovaSeq SP to a depth of >55 million read pairs per sample by the UNC High-Throughput Sequencing Facility. RNA-seq data processing and analysis Raw reads were trimmed and filtered of adapter contamination using cutadapt ( Martin 2011 Table S2 Dobin et al. 2013 Patro et al. 2017 3 Love et al. 2014 Ritchie et al. 2015 Stephens 2017 Mangiola and Papenfuss 2020 Gu et al. 2016 Gene ontology enrichments were then assessed using gprofiler2 v0.2.1 ( Raudvere et al. 2019 Choudhary et al. (2021) GSE156799 3 Results Development and characterization of a model of O 3 Inspired by previous studies of O 3 Nambu and Yokoyama 1983 Evans et al. 1985 van der Wal et al. 1994 3 3 3 Fig. 1A 3 3 3 3 3 Fig. 1B and C Fig. 1D–G 3 Fig. S4 Fig. 1. A new model of ozone tolerance in mice. A) Female C57BL/6NJ mice were exposed to ozone as depicted, then sacrificed 6 or 24 h following 2 ppm challenge. B and C) Decreased injury and inflammation after ozone challenge in ozone pre-exposed mice as reflected by BAL total protein (B) and neutrophils (C and D) in BAL fluid, respectively. Neutrophil counts were quantified manually using cytospins. Control mice were harvested at 24 h. Differential cell counts were determined using morphological criteria of cytospin slides. D to G) Altered cytokine/chemokine concentrations in BAL fluid were also observed in the ozone pre-exposed group. Histological analysis of large and small airways shows a protective effect of ozone pre-exposure on acute ozone-induced epithelial injury. Light photomicrographs of respiratory epithelium lining proximal large diameter axial airway (A, C, E, G, I, K) or distal small diameter pre-terminal and terminal bronchioles (B, D, F, H, J, L) in the left lung lobe of mice exposed to FA + FA (A to D), FA + O 3 3 3 Prior studies reported an increased frequency of proliferating AT2 cells in the lungs of tolerized rats ( Nambu and Yokoyama 1982 Evans et al. 1985 Fig. 3 Fig. S5 Fig. 3. Changes in epithelial cell type frequencies and proliferation in ozone tolerized mice. Flow cytometry-based determination of epithelial types in whole lung digests. Mice were exposed to 0.8 ppm ozone for 4 days and harvested on day 7. Ki67 expression was measured on club cells, ciliated cells, and AT2 cells. First, utilizing the same O 3 3 Fig. 5A Foster et al. 2007 Allard et al. 2019 Fig. 5B 3 Fig. 5C Fig. S9 3 Fig. 5D and E 3 Fig. S10 Fig. 5. Depletion of AMs using clodronate does not alter tolerance. N P 3 3 P P 3 3 3 Subsequently, we asked whether AMs were sufficient for tolerance by transferring AMs from tolerized mice to naïve recipient mice and then challenging these mice with O 3 Fig. 6A 3 3 Fig. 6. Adoptive transfer of tolerized AMs does not alter response to acute ozone challenge. A) Experimental paradigm. BAL cells were collected from tolerized vs. non-tolerized mice and 400,000 cells were then transferred to naïve recipient mice by oropharyngeal aspiration (OPA). Recipient mice were challenged with filtered air or 2 ppm O 3 N P 3 Discussion We built a new mouse model of O 3 3 3 Nambu and Yokoyama 1982 Evans et al. 1985 3 After establishing a model of tolerance, we set out to evaluate the role of AMs, which have long been known to play a role in acute O 3 Arsalane et al. 1995 Pendino et al. 1995 Dahl et al. 2007 Tighe et al. 2011 Sunil et al. 2012 Francis et al. 2017 Hussain et al. 2020 Tovar et al. 2020 Choudhary et al. 2021 Guttenberg et al. 2024 Medvedev et al. 2000 Nomura et al. 2000 Foster et al. 2007 Piao et al. 2009 3 3 3 3 3 To circumvent the role of airway epithelial cells, we conducted adoptive transfer experiments in which we transferred AMs from tolerized or non-tolerized mice to naïve recipient mice. We found that adoptive transfer of tolerized AM did not alter inflammation or injury caused by acute O 3 Zahalka et al. 2022 3 3 Our results differ from a model of chlorine gas adaptation in which AMs were shown to be critical ( Allard et al. 2019 3 Nodelman and Ultman 1999 Bush et al. 2001 Morris et al. 2005 Squadrito et al. 2010 3 3 Guttenberg et al. 2024 3 3 3 3 Although many genes involved in receptor-mediated signaling and production of pro-inflammatory cytokines were downregulated, we did find that some genes were upregulated by four days of O 3 Spp1 3 Barreno et al. 2013 Tovar et al. 2020 Choudhary et al. 2021 Leroy et al. 2015 Acp5 Tnfaip3 Bune et al. 2001 Vereecke et al. 2009 Tnfaip3 Cd200r2 Cd200r1 Bissonnette et al. 2020 Cd200r1 Cd200r2 Cd200r1 Cd200r2 3 It should be noted that our results were obtained using a single inbred strain, C57BL/6NJ. Given that a previous study showed that adaptation to some inhaled toxicants, including O 3 Wesselkamper et al. 2001 3 In total, our results argue against an important role for AMs in tolerance to O 3 3 Bowers et al. 2021 Nambu and Yokoyama 1982 Evans et al. 1985 3 Supplementary Material kfaf095_Supplementary_Data Acknowledgments We thank Dr. Dan Costa for many helpful conversations about tolerance and adaptation, Dr. Adelaide Tovar for brainstorming sessions, Daniel Vargas and Rowan Merritt for their assistance in performing mouse experiments, the UNC Flow Cytometry Core Facility for assistance with cell sorting, the UNC Respiratory TRACTs Core Facility for assistance with Luminex assays, and Amy Porter of the Michigan State University Investigative Histopathology Laboratory for assistance with histology.
